line_1: I mean to have that kind of useful spirit,
line_2: Which modestly assures us we have merit.

line_1: Her mother's virtues, father's spirit!
line_2: And may sweet Shirley still inherit,

line_1: Says Tom, (who's a lad of a generous spirit,
line_2: And not like young rakes who 're in haste to inherit,)

line_1: And cried, t' obey the Head shew'd want of spirit,
line_2: Each member loudly sounded forth his merit,

line_1: "Of such disinterested spirit,
line_2: "Nothing prevails, with him, but merit;

line_1: A Tincture of the Lawyer's Spirit;
line_2: Then how shall I who still inherit,

line_1: Thus as the same detracting spirit
line_2: Attends on all distinguish'd merit,

line_1: Oh! Lyre divine, what daring Spirit
line_2: Wakes thee now? tho' he inherit

line_1: The rough, unbending, martial spirit,
line_2: The conscious brow of inward merit,

line_1: Its form alone without its spirit.
line_2: Its gay exterior all its merit,

line_1: Will Men of Quality, and Spirit,
line_2: Regard you for intrinsick Merit?

line_1: Thy silent flattery sooths our spirit,
line_2: And we forgive eclipsing merit;

line_1: Contemns their base reviling spirit,
line_2: He, conscious of superior merit,

line_1: Oh! lyre divine, what daring spirit
line_2: Wakes thee now? Though he inherit

line_1: With no Disguise in Speech, or Spirit,
line_2: But Modesty, the Mask of Merit.

line_1: Not wholly void of sense or spirit,
line_2: Yet tho' but small his claim to merit,

line_1: And double portion of his Spirit;
line_2: For I Agario's Muse inherit,

line_1: Have I not dash'd my character with spirit?
line_2: To bully two such Kings was no small merit.

line_1: Scandal is conversation's spirit;
line_2: Bend all your force to spatter merit;

line_1: Thus to confine a Nymph of Spirit!
line_2: Ill-judging Parent! blind to Merit,

line_1: 'Tis a Shame to the Army, that Men of such Spirit
line_2: Should never obtain the Reward of their Merit,

line_1: Who wrote with such Spirit,
line_2: An Author of Merit,

line_1: He swore, drank, whor'd, sung, danc'd with spirit,
line_2: 'Till Phyllis sigh'd, and own'd his merit,

line_1: I'd have you know, Sir, I've a spirit
line_2: Suited to my superior merit —

line_1: That soul and body, matter and spirit,
line_2: With all which men think they inherit,

line_1: With modesty ne'er damps his spirit,
line_2: The lad, of all-sufficient merit,

line_1: Of a most contradicting Spirit,
line_2: And envious of another's Merit.

line_1: One seem'd to talk with mighty Spirit,
line_2: Of baffl'd Worth and slighted Merit:
